importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico occurred on this date in Handlova, Slovakia, marking a pivotal moment in national political turmoil.
The Slovak Specialized Criminal Court issued its verdict on Tuesday, 21 October 2025, sentencing Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison for terrorism-related charges.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from May 2024 to October 2025 marks the timeline of the assassination attempt, the legal proceedings, and the societal and political fallout in Slovakia.

keyTakeAways: A Slovak court sentenced Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison for attempting to assassinate Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024.
Cintula, a 72-year-old former mine worker, public activist, and writer, admitted shooting Fico five times during a public event in Handlova, causing serious injuries.
The court ruled that Cintula committed a terrorist act, not just a murder or attack on a public official, citing the specific targeting of the prime minister.
Cintula claimed his motive was to stop Fico's policies, which he believed damaged Slovak freedom and culture, and described the attack as a 'scream against fear that is paralyzing the society'.

The verdict reflects deep societal divisions in Slovakia, with Fico accusing opposition parties of inflaming anger, while opposition figures accuse Fico of undermining democracy, media freedom, and covering up corruption.

Fico, who has been in power since 2006, returned to office in 2023 and introduced policy changes—such as ending state military aid to Ukraine and reorganizing public broadcasting—that sparked controversy.
Cintula has stated he will appeal the sentence, calling it 'unjust', and the defense argued that not all attacks on officials constitute terrorism.
Judge Igor Kralik emphasized that the attack was specifically directed at the prime minister, a key element in classifying the act as terrorism.
Fico has publicly forgiven Cintula despite the severity of the attack and continues to face criticism over democratic reforms and foreign policy shifts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, a Slovak court sentenced Juraj Cintula, a 72-year-old former mine worker and public activist, to 21 years in prison for attempting to assassinate Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024 during a public event in Handlova. The court ruled that Cintula committed a terrorism offense by specifically targeting the prime minister, citing his motive to oppose Fico’s policies on Ukraine, media, and culture. While Cintula claimed he wanted to stop Fico from continuing policies that he believed harmed Slovak society, the defense argued the act did not constitute terrorism. The verdict has highlighted deep societal and political divisions in Slovakia, with Fico accusing the opposition of fueling anger and critics accusing him of undermining democratic institutions. Fico, who returned to power in 2023, has faced criticism over policy shifts including ending military aid to Ukraine and reorganizing public broadcasting. Despite the severity of the attack, Fico has publicly forgiven Cintula, and Cintula plans to appeal the sentence, calling it 'unjust'.
title: Slovakia court sentences suspect in attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico to 21 years
